variant.note: ITERATION, HABITUALITY AND VERB FORM SEMANTICS Fran); vEn Eynde. University oi Leuven Marla-Theresiastraat, 21 7.5U0O Leuven Belgium
variant.bodyText: The verb form= are often claimed to convey two :Inds of information :
variant.listItem: 1. whether the event described in a sentence Is present, past or future Oeictic information: 2. whether tne event described in a sentence is oresentec as completed, going on, just starting or beirg finished (= Espectual information)
variant.bodyText: It will be demonstrated in this paper tnat one hes to add a third component to the analyale of verb form meanings, namely whether or not they ekprees habitualitv. The framework of the analysis is model- theoretic semantics.

The analysis of iteration and habituality in this paper Is part of a comprehensive semantic ehelysis of temporal expressions in natural ianclueoe. The research on this topic is carried out in the framework of EUROTRA, the MT project of the Eeropean Community. It is reported on P:tEnsively in Van Eynde (1R67). The original motive for starting this research an the fact that verbal tenses and temporal as:xiliaries do not correspond one-to-one in the languages that EUROTRA has to deal with. Compare for initance EN re has lived in Copenhagen for 20 years ran nar boet i Kobenhavn i 2U gr with their equivalents in the following languages DE er wohnt seit 20 Jahren in Kopenhaoer ,4) FR il habite 3 Copenhaoue depuis 2( ens )5i NL nij wooht sinds twintio jaar in Kopenhegen When translating from English or Danish to German, French or Dutch the present perfect has. to be replaced by a simple present. Differences like tnese can be handled in one o, two ways either by defining complex mappings from source language to target language forms in transfer or by oefining mappings between language specific forms and interlingual meanings in the monolingual components.

variant.bodyText: Because c- EUROTRM s eeherence to the principle of "simple transfer" it was quite otvious from the start tnat the interlingual anproacr was the one to opt for. It will, rents, ce adopted in this paper as well. The paper consists of three parts. In the first I will present a formalism for toe rep-eseotation of time meenloos, together with 6 mooel 'f.or the interpretation of those repreSentatiOnE. variant.sectionHeader: THE CORE FORMALISM A Temporal Model
variant.bodyText: The iOrmalief, tnat Will cc usec here has peer definec explimitly in van Evnce, pee Tomos Maes ilF65). In this peper I will only give a snort informal oresentetion of the formalism, concentrating nn th:se parts wnicr will be needec in toe seconc pert,

The model consists of a set of linearly orderec irteryals. An interval is a continuous set of time points on the time axis : A la limite it might consist of one moMent of time : For any pair of intervals one can define their intersection as the set of time points which they share
variant.equation: InJ This set might also be empty, as in 1nZ e It is, furthermore, possipie to define some ba n ar relations between intervals, such as 1 I simul 3 .(I,J) > I part-of 0 c(I,J! d j contain I 3(0,I) I leftover 0 :.<(1,0) 0 rightover I >l).(0,I)
variant.bodyText: These relations are also used in Bruce (1972). (m) the cat sat on the mat wiii, for instance, be analyseo in a basic proposition "toe cat sit on the mat" and the information conveyed by the past tense. Toe relation between both is established in two steps : the basic proposition is first relateo to the interval for which it is said to be true, the socalled time of event (E), and then this interval is related to the time of speech (S) :
variant.sectionHeader: 3 E :)E,S) & AT(E.the cat sit on the mat)?
variant.bodyText: This formula states that the cat sit on the mat" is true at an interval E which precedes the time of speech S. Following Reichenbach (1947) I will furthermore assume that the relation between the time of event and the time of speech is mediated by a third kind of interval, namely the time of reference (R), So, instead of the simple Rel(E,S) we will have a composite Rel(E,R) & Rel(R,S). Net to this relational information the temporal expressions can also give specific information about the location or the length of the relevant intervals. This is typically done by means of t:me adverbials, such as "next year, In the spring', for two years", "till Christmas', et:. This information will be represented by means of one-place predicates over intervals : Fred(E) ' and Fred(P). An exception 15 to be made here for the time cl speecn. whose precise location or length is never specified I. linguistic means, but rather bi pragmatic factors. A possible way tc reflect this- IP the formalism is to treat it as an unbouno variable. In sum, the general format for the representation of temporal information looks as follows :
variant.figure: precedence identity contain overlap I before 0 J after c(1.01) 1( 3 5,5 CRel(R.Sl & Fred )R) & Rel(E,R) & Preo(E) & AT(E,p)I
variant.bodyText: where o is a basic atemporal proposition

For the semantic analysis of the temporal expressions I will start from tne assumption that every sentence can be analysed in two parte : the temporal information expresseo by the tenses. auxiliaries ant) aoverbials on the one hand. ano a Casio' atemporal proposition on the other hand.

variant.bodyText: As it stenos tnis format is not adequate yet to- the upresentation of sentences like ;5) last year they played chess every week (5) he was always late The basic propositions "they play chess" and "he is late' do not hold for one particular time of event E, but rather for a set of intervals whicn are spread in time in some way specifieo by 'every week" in (8) and "always" in :9/. In the following part I will introduce an e:;tehged formalism which can deal with these types of iteration.

Cyclic iteration is marked by adverbials like 'daily", "every Monday", "each year", etc. In e.a. (1972) they are calleo periodic frequency adverbials. For the analysis of these advertials I first introduce the notion frame time. The frame time is the Interval which contains all the instances of the evert described in the basic proposition. jr Fer is true in a world w at an Interval *101 15 true in w at non-overlapping subintervals of i distributed throughout i at periods of e specified lenoth 1. " (Stump 1951, 2261 Stump 5 i-interval corresponds to my frame time, and his non-overlapping subintervals correspond to my I-intervals. As a representation of (8: this formula is not sufficient, though, since the instances of chess plang do not have to take a whole week for (8, tc be true. A more adequate paraphrase is to say that every week contained at least one subinterval (e. during which they played chess :

variant.bodyText: An argument in favor of this refinement is that lancluages have special means for speciivind the e- times. In li last year she arrived at E c clocl, every dao, the adverbial 'at eight o cioci" denotes the location of tra e-interval : (8) last year they played chess every week tne frame time is last year. In the general format E frame time occupies tne same place as the time event in non-iterative interpretations (m the 5-interval:. As where 0 can be any of the following quantifiers e consequence, the formalism predicts that tempohel adverbials which are in the scope of a V always frequency adverbial (e. the e-specifiersi cannot 3 sometimes refer beek to the speech time or the reference '3 never time: * Rd (e,5) and * Rel(e,R). Few seldom, rarely, now ane then Many often, frequently A good piece of evidence for this hypothesis is Most usually, mostly, generally preeioed by the WHEN-adveroials. In general one ten distinguish two kinds of those adverbials : 7nis sixfold division is taken over from Lewis the relational ones, which express a relation k1975). between the reference time and the speech time, such as "yesterday" and "tomorrow", and the non- This anelysis accounts for the anomaly of relatio^al ones, which identify the location of an sentences like interval without any reference to the speech time, such as "between 8 and 9" and "at two o clock'. ‘13) we sometiees played chess every wee 3 The interesting thing now is that only the A4 they often met eveey month latter adverbials can occur in the scope of a frequency adverbial. Compare 7 (15, we always played cress every week V 11 she arrived every day between E and 9 Tress sentences are eemanticeity anenalous * Fe, she arrived every day yesterday because the sene kind of intormetion. namely the vele of ;I, is specified twice. This leads to ince:-e:erncy in j3) End l4 where the 0- Tne fact that the relational WHEN-advereials varleole is said to ge botn universal and non- cannot occur in the scope of e frequency adverbial eh:yersel at the same time, and it leads to provides some positive evidence for not including eleenese in (IF-L wnere the 0-variable is twice direct relations between e and S in the formalise. sale to be ur.iversel. Tne chain-like structure or the representation format is, hence, linguistically motivated. The net question is whether the temporal quantifiers introduce any extra-conditions on those ieterve Is, euch as eA,E), eIee and Pkii.

The format developed for the analysis of cyclic iteration can also be used for the analysis of the temporal quantifiers, such as "always", 'ecmetimes", "never", "seldom" and "often". The leformation tney provide is less specific than the one peovided by the period frequency adverbials, ene tnis should be reflected in tneir representation. As a starting point I take the general format for the representation of sentences with a periodic frequency adverbial :

variant.bodyText: The first of these conditions appears to cc relevant : the temporal quantifiers are indeec interpreted with respect to some given frame time. In ,9! he was aieeys late 'eloays opesnot oenote ALL possible intervals. but only 811 possible intervals In tne past. The coneition that the sueintereals ine.y net overlap dc-as net seen to be relevant. thoueh. In Quadratic equations are always simple

tne instances for whicn "quadratic equations oe simple" are true are not temporally ordereo at all. Iris might indicate, by the way, tnat the 1- oojects are not necessarily intervals, but rather cases or occasions wnich can but neeo not be given a temporal interpretation (cf. Lewis 1975). The third condition concerns the properties of tne 1-objects. In the case of the periodic frequency adverbials the relevant properties concern the location or the length of the Interval. In the case of the temporal quantifiers one could think of specifying a relevance conalticn, for a sentence like 9: he was always late GDES not mean that he was late at any possible occasion in the past, but rather that he was late on all occasions on which his being late or timely coLld have mattered. in Agyisi, Hoepelman I. Rohrer (1980) one can rind a proposal to incorporate this information in the semantic representation, but I will not abut tnis proposal here, since the conditions on the ,,,on)relevance of the occasions are typically oeterminedn, pragmatic factors. in •1S) he always leaves at twelve the relevant occasions (I) could just as well te all occasions on which he leaves as all occasions Or which he leaves for work as all occasions on which he leaves for watching the home game of his fevo“rite football team. As a result of the foregoing reductions ano changes the aeneral format for analysing temporal ouantifiers looks as follows :

variant.bodyText: where Q is replaced by any of (V, 3, '3, Most, Few, Many} M is replaced by some time adverbial wnich specifies tne location or the length of e (if there is any Habituality The sentences discusset so far all contain an explicit indication of iteration. The presence of such an indication is, however, not necessary for deriving an iterative interpretation. Take, for instance, (IQ: he leaves at twelve Tis sentence cannot only mean tnat he will leave at twelve, but also that he has the habit of leaving at tweive. variant.subsectionHeader: The Assignment of Representations to Sentences
variant.bodyText: On the basis of the given analyses one can distinguish three kinds of sentence meanings : This demonstrates the need to distinguise eifferent types of verb forms : the ones that will always elicit an nabitual interpretation, the ones that block the derivation of an habitual interpretation, and the ones that admit both kinds of interpretations. The first are unequivocallv Cehabitua13, the second E-habitual3 and the last will be given the feature [4.f-habitual].
variant.sectionHeader: THE INTERLINGUAL ANALYSIS OF THE VERB FORMS
variant.bodyText: no 1 eratior, o 211 3 \ cyclic periodic P is specified e iteration 011 indefinite F is not specified 172 is any of Ce.3. '3,Most,Many,Few) The assignment of these meanings to particular sentences is fairly straightforward when the sentence contains a frequency adverbial or a temporal quantifier, but if there is none of those, then the sentence is ambiguous between a non-iterative and an habitual interpretation kcf. the twe interpretations of he leaves at twelve"). In practice there are some oisambiguating 4c'torsi, though. I. I,' the Pasic proposition (p) denotes a state, then the sentence can not have an habitual interpretation. Compare
variant.subsectionHeader: The Meanings of the Verb Forms
variant.bodyText: In the previous parts I have presentee a formalism for the representation of temporal information in sentences. Tnis formalism is especially designed for the analysis of natural language, but not for the analysis of any particular natural language, such as English, Dutch or Kiswahili. Its main purpose is to provide a conceptuellv well-definee language for defining and comparing the meanings of temporal expressions in different natural languages. In order to serve this purpose it is not sufficient to heve a formalism, though. Wnat is alsc needed is a general specification of now the semantic representations relate tc tneir language specific counterearts, 1.c. tne tenses, the temporal aexliaries and tne time advertials. The former two will furtner ce called verb forms. For English those verb forms are summec up in tee following re:e )1=, re leaves at twelve Verb form ---> 1+1-Fast] (willeinf) ,2I) ee is in jail car be interpreted as meaning that he has tne naoit of leaving at twelve, but (21) cannot be interpret ed as meaning that he has the habit of being in jail. 2, 0ertain verb forms can block the derivation of one of the two possiole interpretations. Compare ;,12) he is drinking coffee :27) he drinks coffee i22) tan denote a single instance of drinking as well as e recent habit of him to drink coffee ;cf. in the sense of he is drinking coffee nowadays"). (27h, on the other hand, can only denote a habit; it cannot be used to report on a single instance cf drinking. (have+ED) jbe+INO tee going to+inf This rule yields 24 (.2x2x2x3I verb forms. Their role in the semantic interpretation of sentences cen easily be expressed in terms of the given formalism. They specify I. the relation between reference time and speech time : Fel(R,S) deictic information)
variant.listItem: 2. the relation between event time and reference time : Rd E,R i aspectual information) 2. wnether the sentence has an habitual andfor a non-iterative interpretation
variant.bodyText: The meaning of a verb form can, hence, be Hess e examples are useful in this context, represented as a triple sx,y,1-7 wnere x and v are tnouch, because they clearly illustrate the role substituted for one of the possible dinar'. of the verb form in the interpretation. Since it -elations oetween intervals, and where z is one of is the only variable part in the sentences, the the three possible habituality values. cifferencss in interpretation can only be ascribed
variant.listItem: • to them, more specifically to their habituality
variant.bodyText: The same verb form can, of course, have value. different meanings and will, hence, be associated w:th a set of such triples. For the assignment of an habituality value to a given verb form one has to test whether it can or The details of this association have been cannot elicit an habitual interpretation in some
variant.figureCaption: discussed elsewhere, at least for the x and v given context. In testing this one should values scf. Van Eynde, des Tombe & Maes 1985). In
variant.figure: this paper I will only discuss the z values in I. always use sentences with a non-stative basic some detail. proposition, for if the latter is stative the sentence can never be habitual (cf. supra) ; 2. pay attention to the other interiingual values The Habituality Value of the verb form. The English simple present. for instance, is uneouivocally (+habitual] in its simultaneous meaning, but in its posterior A good starting point for demonstrating the meaning) it can be E-nabituell too (cf. the relevance of the habituality value is provided by non-iterative interpretation oi "he leaves at the following list of sentences. They are taken twelye'). from Hese (1985). 24) a text editor makes modifications to a text file ,2!) a test editor is making modifications to a test file )26) a text editor made modifications to a text file ‘27) a text editor has made modifications to a text file In ;24) it is said "that a test editor makes
variant.figureCaption: modifications to a text file in general, almost by definition. We might read this sentence in a. reference manual' 1Hess 1985, 10).
variant.bodyText: In (25-27), on the other hand, it is said "that there is, or was, a case of a text editor making modifications to a text file. These remarks miont be made by a system operator, watching tis screen' (it.). Hess concludes from these observations that the quantifier of the subject is universal in (24) and existential in s25-27). However, this conclusion does not follow automatically. In terms of hthe formalism presented in this paper one could sav that 24) has an habitual interpretation, whereas the other sentences have a non-Iterative interpretation. In the former case the existential quantifier of the subject will be in the scope of tne Most-quantifier, whereas in the latter case it will not be in the scope of any non-existential quantifier, and this accounts for the difference in interpretation without having to postulate two possitle meanings for the indefinite article. The reievente of the i+/-Habitualityl- distinction hes so far only been demonstrated from a monolincual semantic point of view. It is, however, possible to give some translational evidence for this oistinction as well. Tre relevant cases are tne ones where the corresoondino verb forms have different hatItuality .:alues. A good example of this is tne translation of the Dutch simple present in English. The Dntch simple present can be both habitual and n:n-hecit.).al in its simultaneous meaning s28) hi J dninxt alleen whisky ,,simnl,y,fhabitnal: "he drinks only v,Oisky" )29, kijk, hij drinkt ktffie "look, he drinks coffee" The English simple present, on the other hand, is. always habitual in its simultaneous meaning sunless in sentences desoriting states, of course.
variant.equation: (30) he only drinks wnisky <simui,y,+habitua.) *s31) 100k, he drinks coffee ),simul,y,-habitnaln
variant.bodyText: or the expression of simultaneous non- iterativity one has to use the progressive : (32) look, re S OrInkIng coffee As a conseauence. tne mapping of (29) to ;32) inyolves a non-trivial tense replacement, and it is one of the merits of the given formalism that it car handle this jr an interlingual way.

variant.title: THE EXTENDED FORMALISM Cyclic Iteration
variant.abstract: Cyclic iteration is marked by adverbials like "every Monday", "each year", etc. In (1972) they are calleo frequency adverbials. For the analysis of these advertials I first the notion time. frame time is the Interval which contains all the instances of the evert described in the basic proposition. jr true in a world w at an Interval 15 in w at non-overlapping subintervals of i distributed throughout i at periods of e specified lenoth 1. " (Stump 1951, 2261 corresponds to my frame time, and his non-overlapping subintervals correspond to my I-intervals. The first are unequivocallv Cehabitua13, the second E-habitual3 and the last will be given the feature [4.f-habitual]. THE INTERLINGUAL ANALYSIS OF THE VERB FORMS no 1 eratior, o 211 3 \ cyclic periodic P is specified e iteration 011 indefinite F is not specified any of Ce.3. '3,Most,Many,Few) The assignment of these meanings to particular sentences is fairly straightforward when the sentence contains a frequency adverbial or a temporal quantifier, but if there is none of those, then the sentence is ambiguous between a and an habitual interpretation kcf. the twe interpretations of he leaves at twelve"). In practice there are some oisambiguating though. Pasic proposition (p) denotes a state, then the sentence can not have an habitual interpretation. Compare The Meanings of the Verb Forms In the previous parts I have presentee a formalism for the representation of temporal information in sentences. Tnis formalism is especially designed for the analysis of natural language, but not for the analysis of any language, such as English, Dutch or Kiswahili. Its main purpose is to provide a conceptuellv well-definee language for defining and comparing the meanings of temporal expressions in different natural languages. In order to serve this purpose it is not sufficient to heve a formalism, though. Wnat is alsc needed is a general specification of now the semantic representations relate tc tneir language specific counterearts, 1.c. tne tenses, the temporal aexliaries and tne time advertials. former two will furtner ce called forms. For English those verb forms are summec up in tee following re:e )1=, re leaves at twelve Verb form ---> 1+1-Fast] (willeinf) ee is in jail car be interpreted as meaning that he has tne naoit of leaving at twelve, but (21) cannot be interpret ed as meaning that he has the habit of being in jail. 2, 0ertain verb forms can block the derivation of one of the two possiole interpretations. Compare ;,12) he is drinking coffee :27) he drinks coffee i22) tan denote a single instance of drinking as well as e recent habit of him to drink coffee ;cf. in the sense of he is drinking coffee nowadays"). (27h, on the other hand, can only denote a habit; it cannot be used to report on a single instance cf drinking. (have+ED) jbe+INO tee going to+inf This rule yields 24 (.2x2x2x3I verb forms. We might read this sentence in a. reference manual' 1Hess 1985, 10). In (25-27), on the other hand, it is said "that is, was, a case of a text editor making modifications to a text file. These remarks miont be made by a system operator, watching tis screen' (it.). Hess concludes from these observations that the quantifier of the subject is universal in (24) and existential in s25-27). However, this conclusion does not follow automatically. In terms of hthe formalism presented in this paper one could sav an habitual interpretation, whereas the other sentences have a non-Iterative interpretation. In the former case the existential quantifier of the subject will be in the scope of tne Most-quantifier, whereas in the latter case it will not be in the scope of any non-existential quantifier, and this accounts for the difference in interpretation without having to postulate two possitle meanings for the indefinite article. reievente of the i+/-Habitualityldistinction hes so far only been demonstrated from a monolincual semantic point of view.
